free_txt: Data were compiled in SCJAD of Saratov
State University.
Corrected  by  SD and VV:  Updated to new
date formats,  lower  case,  STATUS, ERR-ANALYS, ANG
moved  to  SUBENTs  002 - 019,  BIB updated, SUBENTs
012 - 019  deleted (not relevant to EXFOR), PART-DET
deleted, EN-SEC, SUBENTs 020 and 021 were added.

0.free_text: The sum  of  the ground and  the first-excited-state cross sections.

free_txt: The shapes    of    the    bremsstrahlung   intensity
distributions  at  each   bremsstrahlung   end-point
energy  were  derived  from  the neutron spectrum of
deuterium.  These  distributions   were   used   for
conversion  of  the  neutron  spectra  to  the cross
section.
The  data  were  corrected  for:
(a)  the  background,
(b) the dead time  and
(c) the detector efficiency.
Photoneutron energy   spectra  from  Li-7  have  been
measured  for  bremsstrahlung   end-point   energies
increasing  in  2  MeV steps from 13 to 25 MeV.  The
ground state  and  approximated  first-excited-state
differential  cross sections have been obtained from
8.5 to 23 MeV.  The branching  ratio  to  the  first
excited state has been deduced.
Proton-recoil detector was used.
A 0.5 mm thick tantalum radiator was used.
The flight path = 32 m,  time resolution  =
0.4 nsec/m.
Ratio measurement  of   the  90 degree   differential
ground-state  cross section for the 7Li(gamma,n0)6Li
reaction relative to  the  2H(gamma,n)  differential
cross  section  near 14.3 MeV,  where a ground-state
neutron from 7Li has the same energy (7  MeV)  as  a
deuterium photoneutron,  and the detector efficiency
is therefore the same for both.
A 500 g cylindrical target enriched to 99.9%  of Li-7
was used as a sample.
By the  compiler:  data  were  read from experimental
points,  which were not able to  be  resolved.  Main
features  of  experimentally  obtained  photoneutron
energy spectrum were conserved.
No information.
Data from Fig. 2 of CJP,55,428,1977.

Data from Fig. 2 of CJP,55,428,1977.
A family of pseudo-ground-state cross  sections  were
extracted by using the measured photoneutron spectra
and the  bremsstrahlung  intensity  distribution.  A
composite   of  the  final  2  MeV  regions  of  all
pseudo-ground  state  cross   sections   constitutes
ground-state cross section,  which has been avaraged
over 100 keV intervals before plotting.
Because the first excited state of Li-6 lies at 2.185
MeV  those  neutrons  resulting  from photons within
2.185 MeV of the end-point energy  can  only  result
from transitions to the ground state of Li-6.
The excitation energy after neutron emission.
No information.
Data from Fig. 4 of CJP,55,428,1977.
The ground-state  component  of photoneutron spectrum
was derived from the experimental spectrum  and  the
bremsstrahlung intensity distribution.  The residual
neutron spectrum was  received  by  subtraction  the
ground   state   component   from  the  experimental
photoneutron spectrum for each run. It was converted
to  a  pseudo-first-excited-state  cross  section by
dividing    by    the    bremsstrahlung    intensity
distribution.  The first-excited-state cross section
was obtained as a collage of 2  MeV  tip-regions  of
all pseudo-first-excited-state cross sections.  Then
it was averaged over 300 keV intervals.
Although the  1.377  MeV  gap  between  the first and
second-excited states in Li-6 is  less  than  2  MeV
end-point  steps  an approximate first-excited-state
cross section may be extracted from the Li-7 data.
The excitation energy after neutron emission.
No information.
Data from Fig. 4 of CJP,55,428,1977.
The data were obtained by summation of the ground and
the first-excited-state cross sections.
The high limit of excitation  energy  after  neutron
emission.
No information.
Data from Fig. 4 of CJP,55,428,1977.
No information on sources of uncertainties.
Data from the text on p.433 of CJP,55,428.
